description:
Bipolaris sorokiniana ND90Pr is a fungal plant pathogen that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is the causal agent of common root rot and spot blotch diseases in various cereal crops, particularly wheat and barley.

This species is characterized by its ability to produce dark-colored, septate hyphae and conidiophores that bear multiple, elliptical to obclavate conidia. The conidia are typically brownish-olive in color and have 3-7 transverse septa, giving them a characteristic bipolar appearance.

Bipolaris sorokiniana ND90Pr is known to infect the roots, crowns, and leaves of its host plants, causing a range of symptoms, including discoloration, necrosis, and reduced plant growth and yield. The fungus can survive in plant debris or soil, and its dispersal is often facilitated by wind, water, or seed transmission.

Understanding the biology and epidemiology of Bipolaris sorokiniana ND90Pr is crucial for the development of effective management strategies to control the diseases it causes in cereal production systems.
